reviewText: World War 11 films that depict "Patriots and Quisling's"- the stoic, furtive, passive and violent civil resistance to the Nazi/Japanese Occupation of conquered nations were extremely popular with wartime audiences ."Joan of Paris"{1941},"This Land is Our Land"{1942},"Hangmen also Die"{1943}, "The Moon is Down" 1943, "North Star"{1943},"Edge of Darkness"{1943}, "China"{1943}, "Dragon Seed"{1944}, "The Seventh Cross"{1944}, "To Have and to Have Not"{1944} and "Hotel Berlin"{1945} are all outstanding examples of well crafted movies of this type."The Cross of the Lorraine" is arguably the best and most representative example of this genre {along with the excellent "Hangmen Also Die" and "The Moon is Down"} because it is so grim, gritty and realistic. Its screenplay stresses character development by showing Frenchmen and Germans "warts and all" as venal opportunists, self sacrificing patriots, sadistic bullies, men who have lost their faith and courage and then regroup within themselves to find redemption. The film depicts the betrayal, starvation, brutalization, deprivation ,despair and ulitmate vindication of a diverse group of draftee French soldiers caught in the German Blitzkrieg and discover that the surrender of their unit {by order of their commander} to the Nazi's is only the beginning of their "Hell on Earth"!As usual, MGM spared no expense assembling a superb roster of players. Jean Pierre Aumont {Paul} is the idealistic lawyer, patriotic but not fully cognizant of all the horible ramifications of the Nazi's "New Order". Gene Kelly {Victor} minus his dancing shoes plays a belligerent taxi - driver who goes too far in defying the prison camp guards and is nearly tortured to death AND in the process becomes a cringing hollow shell of himself. Sir Cedric Hardwicke is outstanding as "Father Sebastian" soft spoken and steely -willed who by refusing to knuckle under to the camp commander's order not to perform religious services will pay the ultimate price. Richard Whorf as the officer doctor trying to save lives with no medical supplies and Joseph Calleria as "Rodriguez" a political prisoner {aka, Communist} turned volunteer soldier - both are properly cynical and realistic in their assessment of what the Nazi victory and occupation means: they're lousy,lying bastards who cannot be redeemed and need to be wiped out. AND as the twin axis of evil, Hume Cronyn {Duval} the fawning collaborator and Peter Lorre {Sergeant Berger} a thieving little bully with both of them being sadistic torturers of the camp inmates - but in completely different ways !! You may recognize Richard Ryer {who portrays P. Lorre's superior Lieutenant Schmidt} as the sour faced aide to Major Strauser in 1942's "Casablanca".The film has a significant amount of violence and a "slam-bam" climax but that is incidental to the real theme of the film - that despite the travails of defeated men who are betrayed, swindled, starved and abused - the will and spirit within them {and the civilian population} to survive and to fight in any way possible for freedom from oppression will ultimately prevail AND they will not stay defeated !! This is what the 1944 movie audiences expected to see and believed in and this theme resonates just as strongly in 2013-14, the Nazi's and the "Rising Sons of the Nippon" {and the terrorists that the U.S.A. faces today} had/has to be taken seriouly, confronted and defeated by the entire nation and the costs will sometimes be very high!.Director Tay Garnett keeps a tight rein on the actors - there is no overacting or mock heroic gestures in this film. The production values are outstanding and Cedric Gibbons art direction is {as usual} brillant. This is one of my favorite war films of all time and on all the merits of it's storyline, acting, production and direction - I give this film an enthusiastic 5 star rating.
summary: Grim,Taunt, Tightly Written, Superbly Acted War Melodrama - MGM firing on all Cylinders !

reviewText: Gene Kelly trades his dancing shoes for combat boots and really shines in this shockingly violent film, which makes up in nail-biting tension what it lacks in subtlety. The scenes between Gene and Peter Lorre in the prison cell are as brutal as anything from the era, and the big escape scene with Jean Pierre Aumont driving the get-away ambulance will put you on the edge of your seat and keep you there. Kelly's acting chops are really showcased here, as his cocky, defiant spirit is shattered by his prison experience, transforming him into a broken emotional invalid.But that's BEFORE the final moments of the film. When the wily, dashing JeanPierre unexpectedly turns the tables on the Nazis, we see a brief close-up of Kelly's tormented face, the explosive will-to-fight rekindled within him---a split-second image that continues to dominate my memory of this film 40 years after having first seen it on local TV.It's about time that MGM-Warner's got around to releasing it commercially, even in the lame "Play Only" format.A solid, extremely intense, and entertaining morale booster produced during the war's darkest days. The ending is so over-the-top it's almost operatic----but you'll stand up and cheer!LRPS-- Just watched the film again today (Jan 27, 2014); it's so darn good that I'm upping my rating from 4 stars to 5. Why? Because it is so expertly structured, paced, and directed. Each scene gives you JUST ENOUGH vital information to identify with the characters and the manner in which they evolve--especially Jean-Pierre Aumont and the way in which he takes over Duval's role as liaison with the Nazis and, in spite of the deterioration of his relationship with his comrades, gradually begins to hatch his daring plan to secure their release and that of his pal Gene Kelly.Also, the interplay between Jean-Pierre and Peter Lorre, who changes in an instant from sadistic bully to flustered, subservient lackey when his commanding officer chews him out for his incompetence, is deftly scripted and carefully guided by director Tay Garnett's hand.Other examples are the separate scenes between Jean-Pierre and Gene in the office of the camp commandant--- once again, superbly scripted and executed onscreen.These are but a few examples of the superior craft that went into the making of this totally overlooked gem.
summary: Terrific, violent WWII potboiler starring Gene Kelly

reviewText: The Cross of Lorraine, the free french army fighting the Germans. Too slow, too talky sometimes. Kelly playsa stubborn soldier, who is often too stupid than stubborn. Aumont is pretty good, but Lorre, the executive ofthe prison camp, is wonderful bad. That's why you should see this movie.
summary: Typical Propaganda, but Lorre is wonderful

reviewText: Rousing story of French soldiers defeated by the German invaders in 1940.  They are forced in Prisoner of War camps and suffer abuse.  A few escape the prison and make their way to freedom and continue the fight with free french forces.  A good story and cast.

reviewText: This is a great War film starring Jean Pierre Aumont, Gene Kelly, Sir Cedric Hardwicke, Richard Whorf, Peter Lorre, Hume Cronyn, plus others! Warner Bros. did a good job on transferring this to DVD. The movie (1943) is in B&W, Full screen format and runs for about 90mins (1hr 30mins). Overall this is a great movie and I would recommend this.
